content.description: Go up the left-leaning ramp and step right to two vertical seams. Make thin balance moves past three widely spaces bolts.
content.protection: Three bolts. (Eds. these have been chopped at times over the years.)
content.location: This is on the left end of the main crag at the bottom of a left-leaning ramp / offwidth.

content.description: This is one of the finer routes here. It ascends an obvious crack that is typically laybacked. It just begs to be climbed. The crux is mid-height where it jogs left. Continue up. Enjoy. Zipper is one of the nicest short routes in New England, IMHO.
content.protection: It is easily protected with either cams, hexes. or stoppers.
content.location: This is the obvious flake in the center of the main wall.

content.description: This is a fun little boulder problem. Just climb the crack to the top.
content.protection: Pad.
content.location: Take the main trail west from the parking lot till you hit Pink Floyd Wall. Go to the left end and follow along the side of the highway past Floyd's Chimney. You will see this about 100 feet further west along the highway.

content.description: This is an awesome beginner's trad spot. There are a multitude of was you could make your way up this rock on nice cracks.
content.protection: Standard rack. TR anchors on top.
content.location: This it the chunk-oh-rock right of Toe Jams and Happy Feet, before the walk up to the top.

content.description:
Wink Van Ripple is a really nice little slab line.   

  This is listed on MP as a variation to "No Bolt," but, having cleaned it off recently, it really goes as an independent line and is worthy of its own page.   This may be the hardest route on this small section of cliff.  There are several small holds but none are very good.   

  The lichen has been scrubbed, but it's still dusty and could use more scrubbing.  The mossy bottom in current conditions (dank, muggy July) is rather slick.
content.protection: Toprope this using the anchors for Rip Van Winkle.  If you want to avoid a big swing run a directional (long sling) off a tree at the top of this climb.
content.location:
Start left of the tree and right of the flake of no bolt.  Use the nice rail/ripple for you hands and a short, vertical seam for your feet, then smear gently upward.    

  You will pass a bolt hole on your right during your tenuous journey upward.

content.description: This line starts on a thin, right foot on the face and two wide, inward hands. This first move and half is the crux and is probably where the name comes from. Once you attain the large jugs midway up, the gritty of it is over with. Follow the jugs to the single bolt 5 feet from the TR anchors.
content.protection: This line does certainly go on gear. Use c3s and rock pro around the crux. I am not really sure why the single bolt was placed. The top half is more of a runout.
content.location: This line is to the right of Roll the Bones. Start on the block right of the tree and left of the left-leaning, ugly rail.

content.description: This ascends the very blank arete and face to the left of High Me.  It is very thin starting out and requires Herculean body tension as you smear on the face and grope and undercling the arete.
content.protection: No pro, so use top-rope anchors for High Me on the top of the face.
content.location: Start as for High Me, but once you reach the ledge, ascend the arete behind the large pine tree.

content.description: Smear up the entire length of Zipper a couple of feet to the right. Using Zipper at any point is considered off route.
content.protection: Bring BD Camalots #0.4 - #1.
content.location: This is a few feet right of Zipper.

content.description: Toe Jams climbs a toe-width crack on the far right end of the main wall. From the bottom, scramble up and right over blocks to the base of the crack. Belay from here or the bottom, bottom recommended. Hand and fist jam with ease up the low-angle crack until it becomes shallow and face holds appear. Bolts up top for anchor.This crack is a wonderful introduction to jamming for beginners. The crack itself isn't long or sustained, but offers quite a few moves of compulsory hand- and toe- jamming.
content.protection: Light rack of gear to 3". Hexes and cams. Belay at trees or bolted anchors. A toprope can easily be rigged by walking up the path next to the route and anchoring the trees.
content.location: This is on the far right side of the main Red Rock face. It is a hand crack hidden by trees, with blocks at the base.

content.description: This is a variation start for High Me, Zits, Morning Glory, or Steps. It's the short slab right of the right-leaning ramp which is listed as the start of Steps in Boston Rocks.
content.protection: A pad to protect the landing would be a good idea. Other than that, there are TR anchors at the top.
content.location: This is just left of the left-leaning ramp that Zits and Morning Glory start on.

content.description: Move up the slab either as a starting variation for the Stonehange Boulder or top out the same as Seappage. The crux is getting off the ground.
content.protection: TR.
content.location: This is the small slab to the left of the Stonehenge Boulder.

content.description: This is the direct start for Steps. Smear up the slab directly underneath the main crack of Steps.
content.protection: There is no protection for a lead on this section of the climb, so a pad would be nice if you really wanted a lead on this.
content.location: This is the blank face just below the main crack of Steps.

content.description: Climb up the ramp at the left end of the crag, and then make reach up and into the left-facing flake/crack (sometimes there is a bolt), and follow flake to the top. The step over into the flake is 5.8, and the rest is only 5.5-ish.
content.protection: Mostly medium cams and one bolt that comes and goes. Tree anchor.
content.location: This is on the left end of the main wall and is very obvious.

content.description: Starts just right of Rip Van Winkle on obvious ripples then moves up onto the super rounded arete on the merest of features, then head left to anchor of Rip Van Winkle.   It is definitely thin but all there.   Good intro to hard smearing.
content.protection: 2 eyebolts to anchors.  Top rope with Rip Van Winkle's anchors.
content.location:
This is the obvious bolted route on the arete right of Rip Van Winkle.  

  Note: this climb is located on the right side wall -- a little wall just past the walk up to the top of the main cliff.

content.description: This is a sweet, short line. Wedge between the slab and the ledge.
content.protection: BD #1 and below. Sling off tree on top.
content.location: This is the fartherest line to the right on the north end.

content.description: Follow up the arete to some cool little rails, follow up the the short hand crack left of the tree. The bottom half may be wet for a while after a good rain.
content.protection: Gear or long sling for TR. If you go for the lead, watch out for the crippling landing.
content.location: This is on the left side of the Stonehenge Slab.

content.description: Follow up the easy bottom half of the slab. Step up into the horizonal crack and make delicate moves up the slab just left of the center.
content.protection: TR. Either use a sling from the tree or make a gear anchor in the crack on top.
content.location: This is the first slab as you approach the main wall on your left.

content.description: This is a nice bit of friction on the smaller face to the north (right) of the main face. It is essentially a one-move wonder. Climb the Zipper-like flake at about 5.5. Protect well where it ends, about 8 feet below the top. The climb consists of navigating this blank section. Smear and trick your way through to some uninviting slopers (only one or two moves of .10a) and top out. It is scary above the gear!
content.protection: Small cams and nuts. The flake is never wider than green Camalot size.
content.location: This is on the narrow face to the right of the main face. The flake is an obvious feature.

content.description: Start below Toe Jams to the right of Laughing Gull. Smear your way up to the right of the crescent dike of Laughing Gull and up to the left-leaning crack.
content.protection: Two bolts and BD Camalots #1 and #2.
content.location: This is a variation of Laughing Gull.

content.description:
This is a fun, moderate climb, independent of the routes on the main wall, providing a nice alternative when those routes get backed-up. 

  Climb the left-facing corner/flake using good foot ledges, then pull onto the upper slab/face.  Follow the features on the blunt arête (right side of the face) using dishes and knobs, past a wide crack, moving slightly left at the top to good finishing holds and the anchors. 

  Please do not top rope off the ring anchors, which decreases their lifespan and safety.  Instead, place your own draws, and have the last climber in your party thread the rings and rappel (not lower).
content.protection:
5 bolts to ring anchors.

 Update: There are shiny new anchor bolts about 6 feet above the ring bolts.  Presumeably these are for easy access to top-roping.
content.location:
This route is located slightly left of (before) the main wall, at the smaller buttress marked by a pile of large blocks at its base. 

  Approach the base, then trend up and left to an obvious left-facing corner/flake behind a tree.  You cannot see the route from the trail.

content.description: Head up Zipper, about 8 feet from where the flake jets out left, head straight out to the right where the left-leaning crack from Laughing Gull tapers out. On delicate feet on good scoops, make the traverse across the q   Y d nugand head up the crack of Laughing Gull.
content.protection: This can be lead with BD Camalots #0.4 through #1, a blue nut in the corner of the Zipper is a good piece before heading out to the right.
content.location: Start up Zipper.

content.description:
Cram yourself in the low-angle offwidth, then get up it however you can. You know you want to!

 This can be done in part or in full as an alternate start to any number of the climbs around it, or you can finish at the pine tree and walk off.
content.protection: Small to medium nuts and cams plus your bruised and battered body. Continue up onto another climb, or belay off the tree to the left of the exit from the offwidth.
content.location: It's the left-leaning offwidth/ramp that splits the starting moves on "Steps."

content.description: Climb the entire slab just right of Steps.
content.protection: None. TR anchors on top.
content.location: This is just right of Steps.

content.description: Pull up on the right-facing flake, grab the arete, and shimmy to the top. The 5.11 variation moves straight up the slab the under the arete. The arete is off.
content.protection: No bolts. No TRs. If you want to top rope this, you can use the anchor above Rip Van Winkle.
content.location: This is the first line on the left of the North End.

content.description: Move up the left-leaning ramp. Step right to bottom of Steps crescent. Move up a tall move to a short dike. Mantle and move to the top.
content.protection: One bolt...now there are 3 bolts.
content.location: This is on the left end of the main crag at a left-leaning ramp / offwidth.

content.description: This is the crux of slab climbing. Start on Ray's Picture and traverse over toward Steps, across Morning Glory, past Zits, take the horizonal crack halfway up the slab next to high me and smear up the left side of the Chimney.
content.protection: TR?
content.location: This route crosses the entire face of main crag. start on the right and ending on the left end.

content.description: Start on the placed flat stone just right under the first bolt. Smear up to the left towards the cresent dike. Hand foot match on the right leaning crimper on top the dike. Smear straight up towards the "peanut". Once you are standing on the "peanut" you can traverse right towards the second bolt, across a nice, scoopy plank and make your way up the left-leaning crack. Follow the crack to the top.
content.protection: Two bolts. The crack above takes between a #1 to a #2 BD Camalot.
content.location: This is right of Zipper and Velcro and left of Toe Jams.

content.description: This is the short line on the last decent slab, right of "Slip Van Winkle."  Despite the name, it is actually par 5 or 6!  Grab the obvious hole, pull up, hand-foot match, clip the bolt, levitate up the slab to the crack, anchor off the tree at the top.
content.protection: Pad and a spotter OR 1 bolt, one cam and a long(ish) sling for the top.

content.description: This is one of the best overhanging problems of Redrocks. Follow the corner crack up to the top using rock features to balance out with your feet. The crux is mid way up the corner. The crack tapers out and there's a big step/reach up for a good hold.
content.protection: Pad.
content.location: This one is a little hard to find. You can either try to find it by heading toward the summit of Redrocks from Frosty the Boulder, or you can head towards the highway from the Summit of Redrocks. It is pretty well tucked away, so keep you eyes open. If you end up more than a few yards from the exposed bedrock of the summit, you have gone to far.

content.description:
Make thoughtful moves up the fun slab on the left side of the little triangular buttress (crux).  Exit at the weakness under the tree, traverse right on the ledge, and then lay-back up the the corner.  Exit right at the top of the corner towards a small tree.    

  This may be the tallest climb on the cliff.
content.protection:
TR bolts are left of the corner above the face.  Setting up the TR anchor can be a bit a sketchy, so consider clipping in for safety.    

  I have not led this, but the initial slab is entirely unprotected.  Also, the top of the corner widens to off-width, so one would need wide gear to protect it fully (but it is the easiest part of the climb).   

  It would also be possible to move up the easy ramp on the left to the tree.
content.location: Start on the left of the little triangular buttress that forms the ramp at the start of Morning Glory, Steps, and Zits.  It is almost directly beneath the large tree midway up.

climbs.name: Happy Feet
climbs.fa: Unknown... first lead on bolts by Matt Natti

content.description: Start on a THIN crimp and pull up (crux) to balancy moves on cool features.  The line wanders a bit, so don't think "straight up."  The side wall on the right is in for the start and if you get to the Toe Jams crack, you've gone to far left.  This line was probably soloed years ago, and in fact a Toe Jams variation exits the crack half way and finishes on the upper slab of Happy Feet.  The bolts were added in the summer of 2011 after the line got a good cleaning.  Enjoy.
content.protection: 3 bolts to rings.
content.location: This is the slab line just right of Toe Jams, on the Main Wall, just left of an easy gully.  Standing on a dirt ledge 8 feet up from the actual ground, look for a thin, crescent moon shaped crimp (for your right hand).

content.description: Start low directly below the top boulder. Pull up on a small crip and go for the top.
content.protection: Pad.
content.location: Following the trail from the parking lot west until you see Pink Floyd Wall. Go to the left end of Pink Floyd and pass Floyd's Chimney and the Highway Boulder. You will see this on your right.

content.description: Start on the left-facing flake of the slab that High Me starts on, also just right of Chimney. Follow the flake up to the left-leaning crack which tapers out halfway to a large flake. Where the left-leaning crack tapers out is the crux, so protect well. Go left around the flake to the top... there is also a nice crack on the left side of the top boulder which the TR anchors are on top.
content.protection: Smaller gear on the bottom half and larger gear #1 or even a #2 for the large flake. TR anchors on top.
content.location: This is to the right of Chimney and the left of High Me at the South end of the main wall.

content.description: Start on the leftmost flake of the south end of main wall noted by a streak of moss which currently has a little man carved in it. Smear up the slab to the second horizontal crack and follow it to the base of the chimney. The chimney is kind of awkward till the halfway point, this is probably the crux of the whole route.
content.protection: #1 BD Camalot and below on the first half. The chimney will take up to a number 4 and as low as a number 2 BD.
content.location: Start on the far left of the south end main wall. If you're looking straight up the rock and Stone Hedge's left face is on your left, you're in the right spot.

content.description: This line is the same as Laughing Gull, but after you make your way up to the second bolt, take the slab right of the top crack of Laughing Gull to the top.
content.protection: Two bolts. TR anchors.
content.location: This is a variation of Laughing Gull.

content.description: Start on the obvious flake of the Zipper. After about 10 feet, smear out left past Andromeda, toward the black streak. Smear up right of the black streak to the top. This route also has a A3 or 5.12 direct start from the bottom. If you aid it to the top, it's an A5.
content.protection: TR anchors at the top
content.location: This is just right of the black streak, left of Andromeda and Zipper.

content.description: After 10 feet up Zipper, head out left from the flake. After about 8 or ten feet (3 or 4 steps) head straight up. There is also a direct start which is 5.12.
content.protection: TR anchors on top. You can lead this, place a cam in the Zipper flake before heading out left, also you can place a blue nut in the corner of Zipper where it zigs out left.
content.location: This is about 8 feet left of Zipper.

content.description: This granite wall arguably offers the best toproping in eastern MA. There is one true classic (Zipper), several excellent slab climbs, and some decent crack climbs. All the routes have bolted toprope anchors.Though there a few bolted lines here and there, please avoid bolting established lines. There is a long history of climbing in this area, and if you look closely, you will find the scars of the bolts wars.
